neurotools.stats.convolutional module¶

neurotools.stats.convolutional.blockccm(k, spikes)[source]¶

Generate covariance matrix for linear least squares. It is a block matrix of all pairwise cross-correlation matrices NTrials,NNeurons,NSamples = shape(spikes)

neurotools.stats.convolutional.blocksta(k, spikes, lfp)[source]¶

Block spike-triggered average vector for time-domain least squares filter NTrials,NNeurons,NSamples = shape(spikes)

neurotools.stats.convolutional.ccm(i, j, k, spikes)[source]¶

Construct size k cross-correlation matrix. NTrials,NNeurons,NSamples = shape(spikes)

neurotools.stats.convolutional.ccor(i, j, spikes)[source]¶

Cross correlate spikes

neurotools.stats.convolutional.construct_lowpass_operator(fb, k, Fs=1000.0)[source]¶

Constructs a low-pass regularization operator Get the impulse response of a low-pass filter first Then copy it into the matrix. This really only makes sense in the time domain.

neurotools.stats.convolutional.create_spectral_model(spikes, lfp, shrinkage=0)[source]¶
neurotools.stats.convolutional.cspect(i, j, spikes)[source]¶

Get cross-spectral density as FT of cross-correlation

neurotools.stats.convolutional.cspectm(spikes)[source]¶

Get all pairs cross spectral matrix NTrials,NNeurons,NSamples = shape(spikes) This is doing much more work than is needed, should change it to frequency domain.

neurotools.stats.convolutional.reconstruct(k, B, spikes)[source]¶

Reconstructs LFP from spikes NTrials,NNeurons,NSamples = shape(spikes)

neurotools.stats.convolutional.spectreconstruct(k, B, spikes=None, fftspikes=None)[source]¶

Reconstructs LFP from spikes using cross-spectral matrix. Can optionally pass the fts if they are already available NTrials,NNeurons,NSamples = shape(spikes)

neurotools.stats.convolutional.spike_lfp_filters(spikes, lfp)[source]¶

Cross-spectral densities between spikes and LFP NTrials,NNeurons,NSamples = shape(spikes)

neurotools.stats.convolutional.sta(i, spikes, lfp)[source]¶

Construct size k STA NTrials,NNeurons,NSamples = shape(spikes)
